review_title: If you want to work at a large company, Google's the best place to be
job_title: Program Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Autonomy, trust and flexibility to do you job.  The basic philosophy is to hire smart people and let them get stuff done independently.  The atmosphere and structure is actually brilliant and with nice cash compensation it's a great place to be.
cons: Getting larger and more political.  If you're not working on a project that is clearly important it can be difficult to get noticed by senior management.

pros: For a big company, it hardly gets better. There's a lot of freedom, learning opportunities, lots of great colleagues, perks&benefits.
cons: It's getting into "big corporation" mode. Although company wants to fight it, there is some red-tape. Also, on lower levels of organization, one can get lost in insignificant little things - working for manager who works for manager who works for manager ... etc, has it's toll.

pros: The people. Google hires some of the best talent in the world and as a result of working with such high achievers and high potential people, you find everyone raises their game every day and achieves far more than they thought possible
cons: For the UK, it is only possible to work in London and while that makes sense for the business, I wouldn't be able to work for them again now I have moved away :-(

job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of smart people, fantastic perks. I learned more here than I have anywhere else in my professional history. The older teams, such as infrastructure and apps have people that can teach you more in an hour than you learn many places in your entire tenure.
cons: most of the technology is inhouse, and google faces problems no one else does, so what you learn is non-transferable. Offices outside of Mountain View are treated very poorly.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: The people are amazing, everyone is super talented and smart. Food & other perks are generous. For a large company, has a superbly impressive culture and responsiveness to employees' desires.
cons: Individual team/group culture varies widely, some are a lot more "fun" to work on than others.

review_title: Fantastic place, only when you are working in google office not for there vendor.
job_title: Key Account Manager in Moscow, Moskva
pros: You have all conditions to work, to relax, to feel good during the working hours. No one control you, you have only plan and deadline! You must complete it, but you can do your things while working!
cons: The working in google is a big big challenge. Every day is smth new and challenging.

pros: Benefits are the best.  The work is fun and challenging.  "Work the way you live" allows one to work from anywhere, anytime and using any device.
cons: Long hours and stress can be high if you allow it to be so learning to pace yourself is important.

review_title: Smart people, great ideas... Getting too big.
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Amazingly talented people work at Google. They're eager, smart and willing to help. There are amazing ideas that float around and resources to make those things happen.
cons: The company has grown so fast and so large that things move slowly, management layers are continually being added, and the departments/products get fragmented from each other.

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Great company, strong management, there's no denying the intelligence of most (if not all) of the higher ups. Keep it up!
cons: Moving up the ladder can be much slower than it should be, tendency to value long term goals leads to a fair amount of technical debt that isn't rewarded when payed off

review_title: One of the truly great companies on earth
pros:
* incredibly ambitious -- constantly pushing to think bigger
* cares deeply about doing the right thing
* fantastic benefits -- the highlight is the "death benefit"
* highly supportive and employee-focused culture
* opportunity to work on products used by billions of people
cons:
* has gotten very big
* not as easy to take risks, because the company is under so much scrutiny from so many parties

job_title: Trust and Safety Strategist in Hyderābād
pros:
-Working with some of the smartest and driven people
-Working on cutting edge technologies and products that millions of users use
-Culture
-Perks 
-Great career options
cons:
-Working in a high performing and fast paced environment is not everyone's cup of tea
-It can be stressful at times

pros:
+ good compensation
+ decent work hours
+ free food on certain days of week
+ interesting projects
+ intelligent co-workers, diligent and hardworking
cons: The management can be vague at times regarding their requirements. It is not clear what is asked for, especially from project managers. There could be more collaborative efforts early on before evaluations.

review_title: Google is great, the Paris office a bit less
pros:
Flexibility of the hours allowing a good Work/Life balance
Smart and fun colleagues
High salaries, Amazing perks (food, gym, ...)
Excellent travel conditions
Exciting place to work
cons:
Quality of medium management varies greatly from awful to awesome
Paris office's culture is very "French Parisian" in the negative sense of it

review_title: high expectations and less mobility than you think
pros: decent pay and good benefits. Lot's of young and like minded people
cons:
internal politics, misaligned performance metrics and high expectations make it a difficult environment to get used to. 

My impression was that internal mobility is a rather quick and easy process but it's something that can take 6months or more after you hit your 1 year mark to find an opportunity that is a step up from what you're currently doing. This greatly depends on the organisation you are a part of.

job_title: Trust & Safety Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Great benefits, nice coworkers, great diversity of online reach and access to great tech and (for the most part) relaxed culture.
cons: Recent years have seen (what felt like) an exponencial increase in middle and senior levels of management which have derailed some parts of the organization away from what would be its very worthwhile mission. Increasingly political company.

pros: Great for part-time work.  It is freelance and the hours are totally up to you. Easy to be trained in and management has answered all of my questions so far.  It is fun if you are interested in fashion.
cons: Don't expect to make a career out of it. Apparently they accept almost anyone as a stylist which is upsetting since you would hope they value professional stylist's opinions over someone with little fashion expertise.

review_title: Job is what you make it
pros: Lots of autonomy and ability to move throughout the company laterally. Gives you the ability to make the role what you want it to be, and the ability to move on if you're not getting that learning opportunity
cons: Oversaturated - IMO - Google caps the amount of promotions given every year and with a strong pipeline of talent (both internal and external) I think it's just gotten too competitive to move up. I think you get better titles and skills externally

review_title: One of the best companies to work for
pros:
Great transparency within the company where you can learn a lot.
Abundance of great, intelligent people in the company.
Lots of exciting opportunities within Google.
Great benefits and perks.
Employees are well respected by company.
cons:
Too Mountain View centric. Most key persons are in HQ and most important decisions are made there.
It's a pain for offices to collaborate across timezones. For example, it's impossible for JAPAC, EMEA, and the US to meet together.

pros: Extremely smart people working on some of the toughest technical challenges. Wide range of products that you can potentially switch to if something strikes your fancy.
cons: Company is slowly getting bloated in terms of # of people and pace. No longer is as agile and fast paced as it used to be.

review_title: Begrudgingly praised, hard to advance without an MBA
pros: Great environment to experiment with different roles and find out what type of field of work you would like to do more.
cons: Program Managers fresh out of grad school who pretend like they know the product better than you do will shoot down all your ideas or input regardless of your experience.  There is no clear direction or priorities set with specific projects.

job_title: Mechanical Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: I doubt there is a company that treats any of their employees as well as Google does.  As an employee you really feel like the company shares wealth among all their employees.  The work you do here is high impact and they're very open to letting you figure out new ways to do things.
cons: The company is growing so fast that it is starting to show signs of a more corporate environment that is bridled by bureaucracy.

review_title: Great workplace with great coworkers, projects and perks
pros:
Great workplace 
Great coworkers 
Interesting projects 
Good perks
Job satisfaction
Knowing you are working for a company that can make the world a better place.
cons: Sometimes management decisions and their motivations are not optimally clear. This could also be due to the rapid growth of the company and the number of projects.

review_title: Great company, awesome co workers, but getting really really big.
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Very smart management in almost every department with clear, ambitious vision. Most people at the company are self starters and have a desire to improve whether its making the products, workplace services, or even things like food and transportation for employees.
cons: Company is getting huge, hard to navigate organization. I still believe its one of the best run large companies but at some point an organization will just get too large and loses the agility and speed that it had before.

review_title: Amazing company, really cares about employees
pros: I've worked at several Fortune 100 companies, and Google is - by far - the best when it comes to caring about employee satisfaction and happiness. I get to focus on the work I love without the administrative nonsense of similar jobs.
cons: It doesn't have the start-up feel of other tech companies... but honestly, it's more refreshing than an actual "con."

pros: Great people.  Great perks.  Learned a ton, and learned how to not be constrained by conventional limits.  Couldn't ask for a better job right out of school.
cons: Just too big for me now.  I'm sure it's right for some people, but for me it's just a major company now and not the type of thing I'm looking for.

review_title: Great place to work but not perfect
job_title: Project Lead in Mountain View, CA
pros: Benefits, variety of work, high learning curve
cons: Hard to move inside the org, very political and given its huge size it is much harder to grow in this company than elsewhere. Salaries might be amazing or terrible, and it all depends on the country, its taxes and your level in the company unfortunately, not the job.

pros: Perks/ benefits are good like everyone knows. In most of the teams, eng managers are generally good, they care about your career path, development. Tons of training courses to help you grow at Google (yes all free).
cons: The company is getting much bigger than few years ago. Not *everyone* is hired at the same bar, few did perform worse than others. Besides, depending on the team, the chance to grow (or precisely speaking, promotion), is not the same, some teams are easier than others.

job_title: Account Executive in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Great compensation
Innovation
Creativity
People
Office Space
There are many opportunities for travel and extensive career training.
cons: Google has become a large company with over 50,000 employees around the globe. Many ayers of management have been added. However, there is still lots of innovation happening in different parts of the company such as Google Cloud and Google X.

job_title: Account Executive in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Great compensation
Innovation
Creativity
People
Office Space
There are many opportunities for travel and extensive career training.
cons: Google has become a large company with over 50,000 employees around the globe. Many ayers of management have been added. However, there is still lots of innovation happening in different parts of the company such as Google Cloud and Google X.

pros: Some of the smartest people you will ever work with. The perks do not hurt either.
cons: The management at gTech is clueless about what their workers actually do. It led to poor morale and high attrition rates.

pros: Great pay, benefits, fun environment. I had a fun time, and would definitely recommend that anyone who can work there, should.
cons: The work can be very boring at some parts.  But that is just the nature of the job. I loved it, but that was the complaint that some of my coworkers had.

review_title: The best work place so far :)
job_title: Interactoin DesignerIII in San Francisco, CA
pros:
3P is awesome; People, Project, and Perks.
You will work with great people, googley goolers, open-minded, well-disciplined, and wiling to take a risk and try new things!
You will also work on cool projects that have impact on people's everyday life in the world.
And great great perks will just follow. :)
cons:
Very fast facing, and there are no such rules never gonna be changed so you have to follow.
You should be very active and adjust yourself to the evolving environment continually.

review_title: The Google model remains the best
pros: Benefits & perks. Work life balance (at least on the Sales & Services side). Exceedingly smart employees, and great engagement from everyone (no passengers here). Focus on people, fairness and inclusion. Company future (growth, big bets).
cons: Like everywhere else, but overall no deal-breaker : internal politics, some orgs seem better treated than other (high vs low budgets), company culture & values can feel heavy at times...

job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
- Extreme care for employee mental health, and preventing burnout
- Top 10% of the market compensation and perks
- Lots of exciting projects going on
cons:
- Starting to get weighed down in bureaucracy due to scale
- Some dead end projects floating around, may result in getting stuck unless you're proactive

job_title: Sr Software Engineer in Buenos Aires
pros: A lot of place to grow, plenty of different areas to create awesome and high impact products, reaching millions of people around the world, that gives an excellent opportunity to apply and get knowledge about different technologies and frameworks.
cons: I do not have too many negative points, just a couple NIT points, sometimes it is hard to reach the point in where you are promoted, that is good also, because it puts yourself into test, about how convinced you are about to make progress in your career.

review_title: Google is frgrance of knowledge it is bag of knowledge we are stroring in our little palms.
pros: Google is organisation  who respects all humans they are not judge everyone's problem or fault. They are focusing on only knowledge.
cons: Try to complete our work with passion and incorrect  to keep  our pride

pros: At best it feels like being at the center of the universe.
cons: At worst it feels like a mountain of technical debt combined with yet another annual horizontal program instituted from above.

pros:
Smart people in engineering and product management
Excellent on site benefits and gym, pool, meals, bike storage and showers
Scale of unprecedented size, billions of users
cons: Google Cloud division is heavily invested but poorly managed - programs are poorly run, managers who are very capable leave

review_title: Great place to work if you want to change the world
job_title: Quantitative Marketing Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros:
-- one of a handful of companies with big ambitions on changing the world, and does not restrict itself to core competencies. 
-- startup environment in many teams like Android, Chrome, etc. 
-- surrounded by very smart people who also care about doing things "right" and genuinely want to make the world a better place
cons: -- work/life balance non existent

review_title: A good experience but not for everyone.
pros: Great and smart people to work with; unbelievable benefits; great place for professional development if you seek those opportunities out
cons: Not much guidance in terms of professional development, so the incentive is upon the individual to seek out mentors and guidance on his or her own.

review_title: Great internship experience and responsibility, but it definitely depends on which team you're on
job_title: Associate Product Marketing Manager Intern in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Very open communication from senior management all the way down to interns
Vested interest in employees and personal development (GoogleEDU)
Smartest / most creative people I've met
cons:
Slow recruiting and conversion process
Such a large company that it's difficult to be organized (in terms of knowing how to get a certain piece of information or resource)

job_title: Account Strategist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Amazing, smart, fun, and quirky colleagues
Great brand name on your resume
Open and transparent management
The food, of course
cons: Google is becoming more hierarchical. You can move up through the ranks, but if you start at entry-level, it will take you 15+ years to get to senior management. Use it as a stepping stone to another job outside the company or move laterally and gain experience in different roles

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Salary and benefits are some of the best around. Most departments respect work/life balance. Internal mobility is good. Overall skill level of peers is very high.
cons: Nothing that happens or has ever happened in software engineering is interesting, relevant, or good unless it happened at Google. Prior experience in barbarian companies is considered irrelevant or harmful. Groupthink and NIH syndrome lead to some daft decisions that are considered holy and irrevocable within the company.

review_title: Great employer if you want to work for a big company
job_title: Technical Sourcer (Recruiting) in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Google has lots of smart people working on many exciting projects.
The perks and benefits are unbelievably good.
Management is very open with employees about what's going on with the company.
Google is one of the most impact-full companies in the world.
cons:
Google is a very large company; it's difficult for an individual to have a big impact.
With lots of top employees, it can be difficult to excel.  
Google is very engineering-focused (great if you're an engineer, less so if you're not).

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Whip smart people; A meritocracy where smart people are listened to; They are willing to allocate amazing amount of resources to solve problems. Amazing benefits (food, technology, lectures and other extra activities).  Great mix of interesting projects to work on.
cons: High expectation to achieve.  Sometimes what they say the company's values are and what is actually applied don't completely match.

review_title: Very fast paced environment - you work hard for those amazing perks
pros: Great team. Lots of opportunities to get involved on projects outside the core role. Amazing perks. Learnt a lot. Fantastic hiring managers and teams, everyone that you work with is so dynamic, intelligent and passionate about what try do. Yummy food.
cons: Very rigid recruitment process which makes it difficult to manage candidates. Expectations are super high so expect long hours and to be overloaded. Most recruiters do not get extended after the 11 month contract.

pros: Good work environment, on site food, help you get settled into area and transport to site. Good travel opportunities. Very flexible and gender equal.
cons: Long hours, tight deadline.  Interview process is ununnecessarily drawn out and painful, was rejected after interview twice before being called back a third time and offered position!

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Pretty much all your colleagues are really good. There are lots of interesting projects. The company is very open internally. Benefits are great: food, shuttle, and more... Company culture is great.
cons:
-company is really big now, one person's impact is definitely small.
-much harder to launch new projects now, with so many processes required by law, or by company.

review_title: Great employer if you want to work for a big company

cons:
-company is really big now, one person's impact is definitely small.
-much harder to launch new projects now, with so many processes required by law, or by company.

pros: They have great benefits. Have a variety of different jobs to choose from. Have good salaries and you can call them with any questions and they will do their best to get you an answer.
cons: Some jobs don't last very long.  You might make good money at one job and the next one not so good. Depends on the job and the company you work at.

review_title: It doesn't get any better than this
job_title: Data Analyst in New York, NY
pros: If you love computers then there is no better company than this. I got spoiled there because after the intership ended I then realized how bad other companies are
cons: I can not think of any. you can do anything you wish as long as you get your job done.  nobody looking over you making you nervous

pros: The people are awesome, the compensation and benefits are excellent, Google really cares about their employeea, and the work is challenging.
cons: The overhead to getting work done can be frustrating, and it can be easy to feel like you never become competent at what you are doing because there are always new challenge.

pros: Smart people, amazing perks and benefits, there's tonnes of opportunities internally if you want to move to a different team, challenging work, performance reviews and promotion process is well documented and not some magical process
cons: Some roles aren't well scoped out so there's a risk of not being a good fit resulting in some bad experience, Your manager will determine to a large extent the experience you will have at Google (Bad manager = Bad experience)

review_title: Still a great place to work as an engineer
pros: Work with talented people. Culture is generally friendly to introverts. Good food, lots of other benefits.
cons: Sort of an identity crisis due to size and success - what to do now? Lots of people there who have never worked anywhere else; a bit insular at times.

review_title: Great technology but many cluttered projects
job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros:
- Google has accumulated tons of good technology and many are still on top of the industry
- Great tools for daily work
- Encourage diversity
cons:
- Not every project is created equal, you need some luck to like your daily work
- Big tech debt (yes, even it's Google)
- People are *smart* enough to always move to the projects where they can get promoted quickly, so that means there are also teams that are not popular

review_title: Good for certain kinds of people
pros:
great benefits
great people to work with
good feeling of community
cons:
workforce are very young and geeky
there is a lot of management-speak
they are not honest about bad news

job_title: Senior Staff Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Fantastic people who care tremendously about doing the right thing.
cons: Google has grown very fast, and is struggling to maintain its culture in the face of all the new people. It also struggles to find consistent product direction now that it's branching more aggressively out of search & ads.

review_title: Great place to work, difficult to move up the ranks
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Mountain View, CA
pros: You are working with some of the smartest, most cultured people you will ever meet. The lessons you learn from co-workers is invaluable.
cons: They pay really smart people to do so-so jobs at an entry level. This can be frustrating and the path to more meaningful work is often ambiguous.

review_title: Awesome place to work with incredibly talented colleagues
pros: Immensely diverse and talented workforce, fantastic perks and working conditions. It feels like the most global company in the world. As an employee of Google you feel that you're in the center of the biggest innovations happening right now, and if you're are self-motivated and diligent you will be able to accomplish a lot in this company.
cons: As the company gets larger and larger there's lot of red tape to deal with, and more levels of management are placed up the ladder.

review_title: Work darn hard, but it's very rewarding on many levels
job_title: Senior Accounts Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Incredibly talented teammates, great camaraderie and passion to excel. Fantastic work environment (food, massages, games, etc.). Powerful products.
cons: Not for those who aren't willing to give it 110% and work hard for it. Work-life balance isn't impossible, but you have to be extremely efficient and effective in order to achieve some degree of balance.

review_title: Great company, slow career, except outside after a few years.
pros:
The food is free and always fresh, the tech is cool. 
You can get free tech every year.
You learn quite a bit about the general Online business.
cons: Career management is non-existent. Expect to have reviews where - despite having surpassed all set targets - you get told that you didn't do enough to best the best guy in the team, and therefore you can wait a bit before you can receive promotions.

job_title: Technical Recruiter in New York, NY
pros: Great perks, great environment, great culture.  Everybody working here is smart, friendly, and approachable.  Plus, there are always awesome events; celebrities or performers coming, writers speaking about their books, etc.
cons: The work can be very monotonous, as a lower level employee, input isn't really valued.  As it's a very large company, the scope of what you're expected to do is quite narrow.  They like you to specialize in one thing and ultimately, your value will be determined on how well you execute THAT particular function.

review_title: Amazing place to have your first job, but two years is probably long enough
pros: Amazing smart colleagues, fun work environment, lots of responsibility right away, great perks (food, travel, bonuses), opportunity to direct your own career/work on what you choose, lots of international travel and team events
cons: Unclear career progression, huge firm so little chance of rising through the ranks, employees pitted against each other, questionable hiring decisions (especially at management level), unclear policies, competitive atmosphere, middle management brought in (usually) from outside Google and don't always understand/fit the culture

review_title: Google cares deeply about its employees
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Mountain View, CA
pros:
* work with brilliant, motivated, caring people
* excellent perks: free food, massages, flexible work schedule, wifi supported commute
* extremely fast paced: room for creative problem solving, new challenges
cons:
* extremely fast paced: be prepared to keep up and not be discouraged by the amount of knowledge you're expected to absorb
* too many interesting things going on: can't attend all the classes, author visits, celebrity interviews, etc. -- need to have excellent time management

They like you to specialize in one thing and ultimately, your value will be determined on how well you execute THAT particular function.

review_title: Google cares deeply about its employees
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Mountain View, CA

* excellent perks: free food, massages, flexible work schedule, wifi supported commute
* extremely fast paced: room for creative problem solving, new challenges
cons:

* too many interesting things going on: can't attend all the classes, author visits, celebrity interviews, etc. -- need to have excellent time management

review_title: Google was an amazing place to work at
pros: Google offers an environment that allows you to focus on your work. They take care of your three meals if need be, offer classes of all sorts, provide you with the space to rest, and etc. Even if your work is demanding, it is very easy to relax and take a break.
cons: I would have liked more opportunities to meet different people. In general I think it is a quiet office where people work a lot.

pros: Work with smart people on projects that are changing the world. Future thinking and innovative, always something that will surprise you. Great benefits and life experiences. Everything you do gets noticed in the press. Fun that family/friends know where you work. Campus is like college, there are activities for every interest and all kinds of interesting people to meet.
cons: Bureaucracy of a large company. Lots of scrutiny in the press on anything Google does.

review_title: Working at Google makes other jobs pale in comparison.
pros: Great Talent, Great Perks, Great Vision!!!  I wake up every morning excited about coming to work.  The people are friendly and supportive.  The management is hands off and allows for a solid work/life balance.
cons: I cannot think of any cons of working at Google beside the fact that I am not allowed to tell anyone what I do, where I do it, or how long I'll be doing it for.  haha

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The Google LA office is fantastic. The office is located in Venice just steps from the beach with some of the best facilities including a gym, dog park, roof deck, juice and coffee bar, and an amazing cafe. The office really grasps the Silicon Beach theme of the area
cons: As Mountain View (HQ) continues to grow, you spend more time collaborating with others over video calls and IM, making it a more inefficient workflow

job_title: Associate, Business Operations and Strategy in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Amazing perks and compensation
Opportunity to work with incredibly smart people
Work on cool, strategic problems that can be really outlandish and experimental
See across all levels of the organization
cons:
-Doesn't generally lead to operational work
- Some projects seem nice to have, not critical
- Can be a transitional role

pros: Moving at the speed of light. Founders care about the world and technology.
cons: Lots of external folks brought in agency and consulting type of cultures. It's a "House of Cards" + "Game of Thrones" type of company on a day-to-day basis. If you're looking for a career in politics, this is a great company for you - you'll get more than enough of that. Be prepared to get thrown under the bus oftenly.

pros: Moving at the speed of light. Founders care about the world and technology.
cons: Lots of external folks brought in agency and consulting type of cultures. It's a "House of Cards" + "Game of Thrones" type of company on a day-to-day basis. If you're looking for a career in politics, this is a great company for you - you'll get more than enough of that. Be prepared to get thrown under the bus oftenly.

pros: There is always fascinating, challenging work to do and plenty of opportunity to improve professional skills.  We have the resources we need to achieve our goals.  We enjoy excellent benefits, and the over-all compensation packages are terrific.  It is possible to achieve a healthy work-life balance.
cons: Google is continuing to grow and as we do, it is increasingly bureaucratic... the quality of senior leaders is now uneven, and there is a level of uncertainty about the company's direction from senior executives.

job_title: Program Manager II in Mountain View, CA
pros: Imagine a place that you are working with the 20% people all the time, this is how it is working in Google. You can trust your co-working to get their part done almost 90+% of the time without nagging them.
cons: Still have politics. The company is large, so some things don't get done as quickly. Some overachievers  are trying very hard to shine. If you are aggressive and try to climb the corporate ladder than the competition can be tough.

job_title: Head of Marketing in Mountain View, CA
pros:
+ Fantastic work culture
+ Amazing benefits including great food, drinks and snacks
+ A chance to work with some of the smartest people you'll likely run into
+ Think big
+ Spirit of innovation
+ Family and kid friendly events
+ Friendships that will last a lifetime
+ So many clubs, activities to take part in 
+ TGIF
cons:
- Some of the middle management (Directors, VP) just cruise, doing nothing, acting busy
- Incredibly steep corporate ladder to climb
- Performance review process cumbersome; ratings system ineffective and biased

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Great people, caring co-workers, extreme transparency, strong culture.  The perks are real and compensation is very competitive, but the meaningful projects is what attracted me to Google.
cons: Slow decision making as the company continues to grow at an amazing pace.

review_title: Was the best place to work, now its 'best place of its size'
pros:
- There is a really good variety of projects
- The people you work with are generally of really high calibre
- The perks are really good
cons: - It's too big, the size of the company has not clearly improved its ability to execute whilst leading to an erosion of cultural values

review_title: Perks get old, but good if you like to get comfortable
pros: Lots of perks. Good leadership. Useful products that impact a lot of people. Genuninely on a good mission to improve information access throughout the world.
cons: Too many colleagues were there for the perks and so a lot of them became complacent at work, which did not make for a motivating work environment.

job_title: Quality Assurance Content Editor in Mountain View, CA
pros: The pay rate was agreeable.
cons: Individual work assignment, which could get monotonous. I did not feel like I fit in. The management team already kew each other, so I was the newbie. I didn't really click with anyone.

review_title: It's is as great from the inside as it looks like from the outside.
pros:
1. Extremely talented people around you every day. A perfect opportunity to learn every moment, be it a meeting, a dinner or a coffee break.
2. Impact - every day you contribute to a project or a product which will bring value to users, clients, or public institutions.
cons: It's difficult to adopt to the world around after leaving the company.  Keeping work/life balance and having a clear long-term career plan is paramount at this point.

job_title: People Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very smart people and ambitious projects. Google provides pretty much the comfiest lifestyle you can have.
cons: Feels like a very large company and can be impersonal at times. Commuting to Mountain View gets old quickly. Also, many smart people will stay in roles they don't care for because they get to work at such an amazing overall company.

review_title: One of the best places for young specialists
pros: Best comp and benefits for young specialists, e.g. best medical insurance in Moscow upon my knowledge, including spouse/children. Great internal international mobility opportunities. Fair and transparent promotion system.
cons:
Now a very wide range or horizontal growth inside the Moscow office which might be necessary in case of limited vertical growth opportunities. 
Despite the promotion system is fair and transparent, it does not allow to grow fast, but also demands high self-promotion and stakeholder management skills and this becomes a "second job".

pros: great pay, great flexibility. Nobody pampers engineers like Google. Focus is on small teams, self-starting and self-motivating engineers. Much less power politics than I've found elsewhere.
cons:
no offices.
Excessive focus on engineering means that non-engineering disciplines (finance, HR, legal, marketing) are under-valued.
A lot more boring ads work than you would think.

review_title: Google is a great place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros:
- Great technical talent
- Great software engineering practices
- Outstanding benefits
- Lot of visibility into the inner workings of the company
cons:
- You may land up in a non-important group
- Industry experience is not valued, perhaps rightly so
- Its hard to get promoted beyond a certain level.

review_title: great place to work as an engineer, not so great for other functions
pros: relaxed work sphere, friendly people
cons: non engineers are treated differently, it is slowly becoming a rigid organization, so getting a promotion becomes difficult (depends on your department and how old it is).

pros: Google is an exellent employeer and highly recommend anyone to al least try to employ thier. Google is fair and u get to change the web in which alot of people around the world get to look at.
cons: not as exciting as an active job. Even though you spend alot of time sitting on the job there isnt much to do on the computer instead of working.

review_title: Good if you are not too keen in career advancement
pros: Folks are generally smart and friendly; easy to achieve work-life balance if you are not too keen in getting promoted; open culture.
cons: As the size grows, policities start to kick in. There are people (thankfully, only a few) who talk the talk but not walk the walk that are fast-track in the promotion.

review_title: Fun and still as interesting as it sounds
job_title: Product Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Opportunity for big impact
Fun people
Can afford to do anything they decide to -- its not a startup experience
cons:
Large and growing size means your team and manager are your destiny more than Google overall
Few opportunities to grow into leadership positions
Some things take too long to get done now that there are so many people to consult before locking a decision

review_title: Nice place to while away time but no real career growth
pros: Apart from the brand the bouquet of perks. A nice peer group and global exposure
cons: Overqualified for very basic jobs. They act fussy about recruitment but still don't provide anything challenging to entry level employees in the sales and adwords department at least in the Indian office. Also the perks don't make up for the poor take home salary.

review_title: Great pay, great food, great coworkers
job_title: Technical Writer in Mountain View, CA
pros: People, environment, and pay/perks are great. They really spoil you. Projects are challenging so you really get to grow your skills daily. Coworkers are the smartest, funniest, and most conscientious I have ever worked with.
cons: Pace can be relentless. Not a great place to move up the ladder because there is so much competition. Promotions to management seem pretty political. Your manager may not have any  interpersonal and leadership abilities. If that happens, try to move on quickly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: As far as big companies go, I'm convinced that Google is the best place to work. You simply cannot beat the quality of your coworkers, the perks, the benefits... Google is a company that truly cares for their employees.
cons: It *is* a big company now. I happened to start in 2007, when my team was small and scrappy, which was challenging, but super fun at the same time. The company is certainly much bigger now, and that fun, small, scrappy feeling is fading.

review_title: Great pay, great food, great coworkers
job_title: Technical Writer in Mountain View, CA
pros: People, environment, and pay/perks are great. They really spoil you. Projects are challenging so you really get to grow your skills daily. Coworkers are the smartest, funniest, and most conscientious I have ever worked with.
cons: Pace can be relentless. Not a great place to move up the ladder because there is so much competition. Promotions to management seem pretty political. Your manager may not have any  interpersonal and leadership abilities. If that happens, try to move on quickly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: As far as big companies go, I'm convinced that Google is the best place to work. You simply cannot beat the quality of your coworkers, the perks, the benefits... Google is a company that truly cares for their employees.
cons: It *is* a big company now. I happened to start in 2007, when my team was small and scrappy, which was challenging, but super fun at the same time. The company is certainly much bigger now, and that fun, small, scrappy feeling is fading.

review_title: Couldn't ask for a better job out of college...
job_title: Product Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-great perks (delicious (and healthy) food, nap room, happy hours, latest and greatest devices...)
-passionate and talented people
-open channels of feedback
-companywide transparency into many projects
cons:
-certain roles can be monotonous
-company is huge so naturally there is some red tape (they are very cognizant of this and always trying to improve)

pros: Smart people, colleagues as friends, great perks, food everywhere, competitive pay, lots of learning opportunities, cool to be a part of a generation-changing company
cons: It's a big company which means opportunities for advancement require a lot patience, and it's actually slow to get things done internally as there are a lot of processes, may be becoming more complacent as the company's now a decade old

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: The interesting projects and people are a huge pro for me. The salary is extremely good as well. I'm very excited to see the Company's future.
cons: Work/Life Balance is extremely hard. I don't know why they insist on turning us into slaves. If you have a bad manager, your experience will surely be ruined.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Berkeley, CA
pros: The atmosphere is very helpful and kind! I remember I was Software Intern starting out in this new company. From day one, even the work was challenging but it soon payed off (literally)!  Google also pays a well over average amount and they also have perks like gyms and the never ending food!
cons: Well I can't say much but when you start out it may be very nerve racking but with the help you get you can feel right in the community!

review_title: Talented, driven and passionate team environment.
pros: You get to focus on what you do best. Google tries its best to take care of everything else (within reason) so that you can focus on doing what you do best. Little things like: food, transportation, entertainment, and the right tools for the job ( computers, phones, and even desks)
cons: Since it's becoming bigger and bigger, you get the feeling that you're contributions are not making a big impact. Which leads many googlers to leave after 18 months.

pros: Google has a very positive and accepting environment, a tremendous amount of resources, and significant employee freedom. Great benefits and opportunities to learn from your colleagues.
cons: Google prides itself on a startup culture that has long since gone. It is extremely corporate in the American style, which can be tiresome. There's a very big visibility culture where being loud and 'present' is very beneficial.

pros: Interesting projects, many smart people, occasionally interesting people, perks are good, great ability to learn
cons: Many projects don't make money or are a challenge from a go-to-market perspective so it can be very difficult to attract the talent needed for the role, hiring committee is sometimes our own worst enemy, ad revenue is down and it is felt throughout the organization, there are a lot of jerks and everyone has an edge- they may be ok to work with but you aren't going to make friends here

pros: None at the moment which can be shared.
cons: Free Food, Amazing Culture, Work from home

job_title: Sales Director in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Smartest collection of co-workers I've experienced
Global scale projects to work on help make the work satisfying
Even as it becomes more bureaucratic I always believed they genuinely care about their employees
cons:
Your experience may vary depending on team, manager etc.
If you are passive about your career growth, it may not match the trajectory you hope for
While better at it than most, its simply a very large company with the accompanying bureacracies

pros:
Great place to work, great perks. 
Ability to work with some extremely intelligent people.
Always being surrounded by smart minds.
Not a cutthroat atmosphere, yet the environment fosters work.
cons:
Poor chances for promotion,
Lilmited propsect to work on interesting projects.
The downside is that you might risk getting yourself pegged as a generalist or a Jack-of-all-trades.

review_title: Fantastic place to work; still a big company
job_title: Product Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Google spoils its employees. Free breakfast lunch and dinner, great amenities, and budgets never seem to be an issue (at other jobs I've had to beg travel budget -- at Google, I can pretty much take any trip I think is worthwhile). They also do tons to reduce friction as an employee.
cons: It *is* a big company. Things don't turn on a dime; there is a lot of process. And it is *very* engineering directed.

review_title: Good salary and benefits, but no opportunities for growth unless you are in the US.
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Salary, offices, massage, benefits, people. Google looks after you, from food to flexible working hours. If you are geek that loves tech this is a place for you.
cons: Mediocre middle level managers, with no experience. Impossible to move files internally as the majority of roles are already taken before they are even advertised.

review_title: Why You Should be an Senior Software Engineer
pros: Flexible hours and creative outlooks competitive job with lots of young people. Amazing salary, I get to go around the world for free on business meetings!
cons: Hard-to-get-into-job, can be stressful at times and is typically a good jobs for work-a-holics. Lots of boring and uneventful updating on google servers

review_title: Great Place to Work...Most of the Time
job_title: Senior Sales Engineer in Ottawa, ON
pros: Fantastic work environment for staff at various main offices, great people, great pay, amazing benefits, always on the leading edge of just about everything
cons: Way to much travel, lots of HR overhead, 20% time is really 120%

review_title: Amazing company, but getting big and a bit bureaucratic over time
pros: Amazing culture, perks, growth mindset, most employees are very capable
cons: Company has reached a size and a complexity where most roles even at senior level are rather narrow in scope, and there is a lot of "work about work" - Agreeing who does what, defining processes - One can grow impatient and weary

pros: Products with real impact. My managers were between a little distant/irrelevant and active advocates for me navigating the bureaucracy. Co-workers were generally very competent engineers who  really tried hard to do the right thing. Engineering tools generally work very well. There are loads of nice benefits.
cons: There's a big gap between vision and execution. The Google machine moves slowly.  The products are what can be built and launched after passing 101 reviews.

review_title: Amazing place to develop technical skills
job_title: Technical Account Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- You can learn technologies
- Work with super smart people
- Often ability to craft your own role and experience
- Develop deep expertise
cons:
- Lack of structure, which makes it often hard to figure out everything at the beginning
- No clear developemenet path or criteria to become the manager

review_title: Great company, experience varies by management/region
pros: Incredible perks that you don't see anywhere else
cons: not a lot of upward mobility past a certain point (directors/managers are hired from outside except for in Eng.) Also while some managers are incredible and gifted, others are not and the only option for development is basically to transfer orgs.

pros: Excellent infrastructure, marvelous work atmosphere and supportive management are the major pillars that glued me for years to stay in the organization. Shadow infosystem pvt ltd is genuinely a great company that has provided exceptional opportunities to many struggling professionals like me. I entered as a beginner and left the place with a bag full of industry knowledge. I must say that working with Shadow is one of the incredible experiences of my life!
cons: I Have no Cons.It Is a very good company.

pros: Good communication of objectives by supervisors. Good resources given to employees. Innovation and creativity are encouraged. Good reputation and program. Good future within the company or even elsewhere when you have worked for Google.
cons: I did not have many negative factors affect my work at Google. My pay was maybe as little lower than with other companies, but that's me maybe being greedy.

review_title: Good Place - Lots of New Projects
pros: We work on a lot of really great stuff that is leading the Internet Revolution.  We have a lot of autonomy to work on different projects and make our own decisions.
cons: Management is sometimes a little disconnected and the bi-coastal structure sometimes makes it hard to collaborate effectively and move forwards with projects.

review_title: Best company to work for in the world. I'm blessed to be working for Google.
pros: Perks, opportunities, work environment. I'm extremely  fortunate to be working for Google. The company's value system is highly appreciated across. It's an equal opportunity employer.
cons: Slow growth in terms of roles, It's hard to fill in this space with 20 words as there are not many cons. career development is the only area where I feel they should make some changes.

review_title: Unlimited resources to change the world, if you want to be a cog.
job_title: Product Manager in New York, NY
pros: Unlimited resources.  Leading products.  Smart energetic co-workers.  Great perks.
cons: Competitive to a fault.  The review process is entirely political.  There's a echo chamber.  Your individual contribution is probably irrelevant to the company as a whole.

pros: Great benefits, good work-life balance. Everybody is extremely friendly and helpful. You will find a lot of smart and interesting people, seems like everybody has a cool story to tell. I liked the companies approach for projects and creativity: If you have an idea you will be encouraged to work on it and make things happen.
cons: Lack of transparency...sometimes I was shocked how little people knew about other departments / products / worklfows, considering how essential it is to be aware of the bigger picture.

job_title: Relationship Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great perks, coworkers, flexibility & pretty solid compensation (not the highest but the other bene's make up for it)
cons: Promotions in the Ad Ops team were hard to come by.  Incredibly competitive, had to outshine your neighbor and be your own PR person.  Lots of BS and busy work.  No sense of contributing anything valuable to your team.  Micromanagement and ever stringent review process - bar is always being raised.

job_title: Senior Analyst in Mountain View, CA
pros:
They treat people like adults - not checking up on your every move. There is a great sense of humour in the way they do things. The salary is great, and best of all, you get to make a difference to 100's of millions of people. 

-Amazing perks.
- Great co-workers
- Good work-life balance so far. Hardly anyone works at the weekend in my team and most people are out of the office between 5 and 6.
cons: It's easy to feel intimidated by the talent surrounding you.

review_title: Best Company I worked for in my entire career
pros:
World-changing work, making the world a better place.
Best crowd of people you can find.
Never a dull moment.
Always on the cutting edge.
cons: Chaotic environment, not for the faint of heart.

review_title: Maybe the Greatest Company of our Generation
pros: Super inspiring mission. Lots of really interesting projects. Amazing people, many of whom have been at Google for a very long time. Able to move around and guide your own career.
cons: Some people aren't happy in their current roles and don't know how to navigate a change.

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros:
- Access to a vast wealth of technical resources and people
- Culture where engineers are encouraged to push on ideas and lead
- Strong benefits
cons:
- Given large size of company, often easy to get lost among thousands of other employees.
- Other employees are often focused on personal development and promotion rather than for the team.

review_title: Great place to work as expected, but also very much a cooporate
pros: Awesome culture as you would expect. People are smart and easy to get along with.
cons:
At times the company felt slow moving and very corporate with lots of top-down decision making that feels detached from the engineers on the group. 

You never feel like you are working on the coolest Google product, there are so many.

Although culture is friendly it doesn't feel like a family.

job_title: Software Engineering Intern in Mountain View, CA
pros: Opportunities to work with brilliant minds. Team full of impeccable role models. Surrounded by ego-less, skilled professionals who also know how to have fun! All the famous perks.
cons: Nothing that I think would be standard across many people's experiences. I wasn't a fan of MTV and found the entire Bay Area dreadful. Being one of the few interns in my building and the only intern on my team, I had some trouble finding other interns to bond with.

pros: O you have got to be kidding me.......
cons: Is ran by a pack of 12 years old  kids.........

pros:
lots of my friends have been laid off from several startups, there is just too much hype in startups, the only stable startups are those who have raised a series C or over 100M , any other start up is too risky
stability at google
cons: no cons to working here

review_title: Feel grateful to work here daily
job_title: Staffing Channels Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: Great manager, perks, they care about their people. The culture in the Austin office is incredible, with a lot of energy. People are willing to help one another
cons: Lots of red tape for decision making, hiring process takes a long time. Mine took 5 months and it was quite draining- worth it in the long run but as the company scales they could work on reducing barriers to entry/time to offer.

review_title: Google Cutting Base Pay of Sales and Cloud Engineers
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros:
Great technology 
Free food
cons: Culture of micromanagement and inexperienced managers in leadership positions, simply because they started in Google Cloud early on. In addition they just cut salaries for sales reps by 10% for mid-market and 15% for Enterprise sales reps

job_title: Software Engineer in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Good food, social life, good work balance
cons: My team lacked diversity. It was filled with Indians who would micromanage you every second which was very annoying.

job_title: Software Engineer III in New York, NY
pros: Smart people, interesting projects. I have never worked at a place where such open discussions are encouraged. Negative and positive feedback are equally welcomed.
cons: I feel sorry for some of the people who start to work at Google right out of college or academia. They are in for a rude shock when they go to other companies.

pros: I like Google for it's transparent culture, free food and other perks (well, but those are baked in the total compensation package anyway).
cons: Relatively flat org means there are few chances for one to advance.  It is not uncommon to have a senior manager with 40+ directs.  There are lots of smart people.  In a way, it is a good thing.  The downside is that a lot of them want to play safe, which hampers innovation.

job_title: Software Engineer III in New York, NY
pros: Smart people, interesting projects. I have never worked at a place where such open discussions are encouraged. Negative and positive feedback are equally welcomed.
cons: I feel sorry for some of the people who start to work at Google right out of college or academia. They are in for a rude shock when they go to other companies.

pros: I like Google for it's transparent culture, free food and other perks (well, but those are baked in the total compensation package anyway).
cons: Relatively flat org means there are few chances for one to advance.  It is not uncommon to have a senior manager with 40+ directs.  There are lots of smart people.  In a way, it is a good thing.  The downside is that a lot of them want to play safe, which hampers innovation.

review_title: Contractors are not treated with respect
pros:
free breakfast lunch, dinner, gym membership, social events, and shuttle to work
smart and interesting co workers
good name recognition
cons: contractors are treated with disrespect. the company makes it unclear what is needed in order to transition from a contractor to a full time employee. contractors are left in the dark.

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Easy work, lots of random cool projects to work on. Get to multitask on tons of projects at the same time. Good location.
cons: Too few opportunities. Engineers can be extremely weird here. I would recommend against this job for another tech company. Direction is vague and erratic.

review_title: It was a great company, but it's not for everyone.
pros: Free gourmet food, coffee and beverages, great benefits, decent salary,
cons: The place is a mad house. There are so many people every where. It takes forever to go anywhere and the elevators are paced during lunch hours. Most of the people are walking around in jeans and t-shirts with head phones on. If you like that than you like Google.

review_title: Great place to acquire skills and social circle for starting your own business
pros:
Great insight into the high-quality software development process.
First class experience in the design of the reliable and robust cloud services.
Smart and creative coworkers.
cons:
Poor career growth opportunities: 1) too few steps in the career ladder; 2) convoluted promotion process.
As the company is instantly growing, problems in the inter team communication become more visible.
Technologies used inside Google in the wide majority of cases are not available externally.

review_title: It really is the best place to work
pros: Career development is always top of mind for managers at Google. I love that we can work on a variety of projects.
cons: Time is always a battle here, there are 19 priority projects that all need to get done in parallel, so you often feel like you're always busy. The feeling is great because you get a sense that you're working on big projects with large impact, but whew, you get tired sometimes.

job_title: Account Manager in New York, NY
pros: Amazing career opportunities and a great place to jumpstart your career. There is a good amount of lateral mobility within the company which is great if you want to make a job change without switching companies.
cons: As Google is getting bigger it is getting more difficult to have your opinion heard and to move quickly within the organization. Promotions can be hard to come by and take much longer here than at other companies.

review_title: Working at Google, while challenging, is incredibly fulfilling and you can be sure of getting honest feedback
pros: Free everything. Really, everything!!! Free laundry, free car for a day, free food, free massages, heck, they even throw in a free annual medical physical right on campus
cons: Career progression is a key problem at Google. As the company is so young, so many of the initial employees are still working there, which leaves very little opportunity for new hires to climb the ladder

pros:
- Great work-life balance (coming from a consulting background, so anything less than 60 hrs a week is great!)
- Outstanding perks - company is really generous to its employees
- Cool projects and products - use gmail for work! no outlook, no lotus notes!
cons: - Complicated cross-functional organization design - company is organized around products vs. marketing & sales. Hard to coordinate and move people across functions to action

review_title: Working at Google, while challenging, is incredibly fulfilling and you can be sure of getting honest feedback

job_title: Software Engineer III in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Good life and work balance. Co-workers has good tech experience, you can learn a lot from them. 
The management is quite flat. Engineer has the freedom to choose project to work on.
cons: It's a large cooperation, so sometimes you are working on a small piece. And even a small launch will affect a lot of user, so you need to spend a lot of time working on details, to make sure you are doing correct thing.

review_title: Google is everything I hoped for
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Amazingly smart colleagues
Great innovation
Being a part of a company that really helps make our world a better place
Benefits, benefits, benefits
Being appreciated
Being apart of something huge
Fast paced and challenging
Freedom to do what inspires you
Tons of growth potential and flexibility to explore the company
cons:
Politics are a thing. A big thing
Hierarchy is inevitable with a company this big, but it is a huge problem here
Self-entitled and pretentious a--holes are around every corner

review_title: Enjoyed being there, but happy I left
pros: Great culture, great people. Very high caliber.
cons: Gets political very quickly as you move up. Also, Google is hiring old school sales people to run sales. It's horrible. My VP was formerly from Dell and Nokia. Nothing at all in common with Google. He did not even understand how the ad auction works. And everyone under him feels like a number.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: good food, fun activities, ok salary
cons: no space (people shoved together in cubicles) that are inches apart, petty management style, no real room for growth if you are not an engineer. Co-workers encouraged to spy and report on each other as part of the job.

review_title: Perks as advertised, but you're in a GIANT company
job_title: Account Strategist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- work with super smart motivated people
- TGIF meetings are awesome
- food is great
- perks and benefits are excellent
cons:
- like any super large company, tier 1 work can get stale and boring
- no clear ladder / path is the sales marketing team

pros:
- Interns work as part of real engineering teams
- Interns are actually treated as full-time employees (with access to the latest internal news, etc.)
- Great development environment
- Great company culture as a whole (transparent, trusting, ambitious, etc.)
cons:
- The size of the company can be overwhelming for some people
- The overall experience depends on how committed your host engineer is to you

Can't really think of anything else.

review_title: Great place to work, smart people but suffers from the big-company issues
pros:
- Amazing peers
- Loads of freedom and latitude
- Ability to grow and transfer internally
- Internal performance and feedback system is quite healthy
cons:
- Big company = not as transparent as it used to be
- Getting things done sometimes takes forever because of legal / privacy 
- Politics in middle management, as everywhere

job_title: Software Engineering Intern in Seattle, WA
pros:
Free food
Good connections
Great work life balance
Lots of fun activities within team and within intern community
Lots of employee benefits
cons:
Intern community not as strong in remote offices.
Can get stuck working on boring projects
Time to get ramped up on systems unique to Google is large. Real work is not expected for full time employees for a few months.

pros: No beating around the Bush. You do well, you're recognized and compensated well. You cannot portray something that you didn't do.
cons: You need to brand yourself.  Sometimes people will over brand themselves. Lots of fossils which may demotivate you. However, some experienced people are the smartest ones around.

pros: Culture, Perks, Smart People, Employee happiness
cons: The work itself can get monotonous so one needs to continuously look out for learning opportunities.

pros: Great benefits. Fantastic name to have on your resume
cons: I loved working at Google until I was unlucky enough to be transferred into a team with a bad people manager. This manager ruled through confusion and an iron fist, most likely because it was clear that the entire team was smarter than this manager. I had no clear direction on my role, or even what the outcome of the project the team was working on, no matter how many times I asked. I quickly became bored and frustrated and soon realized that I was not learning anything new, and the transferrable skills I did bring were not being utilized. That's when I started looking outside the company,  and here is what I found at my new job: 25% increase in salary, 50% more vacation time and 150% increase in bonus target. Once I left, I realized just how old fashioned Google really is regarding Management, Performance Reviews, and other HR-related issues. Perf and Calibration were abandoned by most companies years ago because it doesn't work in identifying the best performers, but at Google it defines you forever. Lastly, during orientation the advice given to the Nooglers is "don't be a jerk". It turns out that I have never worked at a company that had more jerks than Google. The egos and arrogance I encountered were off the charts. It was easy to overlook when I liked what I was doing, but once I was put under the bad manager my eyes were opened to the ugly reality of working at Google.

review_title: Good people working on cool problems.
pros:
- They care a lot about the well-being of their employees.
- Good salary.
- Lots of interesting projects at Google and the flexibility to move between teams every year or so.
- Lots of room to learn from veterans in the field and bullet-proof infrastructure.
cons:
- Can sometimes feel like a small piece of a big puzzle.
- Some teams can have boring projects.
- Sometimes work can feel slow-paced (compared to working in a smaller company or start-up).

review_title: Company full of people running around caring only about promo
pros: Free food and a nice gym.
cons:
People only care about promotion with little to no regard about sustaining a product. Quality has been ran over by a truck and set on fire. This is unsustainable but as long as ad money keeps the party going, nobody will care.

Workplace is full of dreamers and very few doers.

pros: Perks and benefits are awesome. Great people there, I made some friends for life.
cons: Systems are overengineered to an extent that making progress is very slow and painful. It's part of the company culture at this point, so when new systems are created they typically suffer from the same problem.

pros: Great benefits and very competitive salaries. Coworkers are generally nice and talented in their field. Software tools tend to be quite good and there are lots of different projects to work on.
cons: Innovation at the company seems to happen in fits and starts. It's hard to see an overall strategy; over-reliance on ad revenues. Attention to financial discipline is starting to erode investment in employees, and it's unclear if the hiring rate is sustainable while maintaining the same standards.

pros:
•  Free food
•  Free food
•  Free food
•  Free food
•  Free food
cons:
•  Leadership is all over the place, poor decision making.
•  It takes forever to get anything launched due to the review process or lack there of.
•  Worst management I've encountered in my entire career.
